text: General Sir ARNOLD BURROWES KEMBALL, K.C.B., K.C.S.I.. Uppat House, Commissioner on the Sutherland Estates (62), and Mr JOSEPH PEACOCK, Factor for the Dunrobin District of the Sutherland Estates (59)—examined.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39270. The Chairman.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —How long have you been connected with the administration of these estates?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: Since June 1879.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39271. But you have had an opportunity of examining the history of its previous administration?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly. My experience is necessarily short, but at the same time, I have looked into it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39272. And you are assisted by a local factor who will be able to supplement your personal information ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, as regards all details beyond my own knowledge.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39273. I am sorry to have to ask you, in the first instance, some questions regarding what passed at Helmsdale the day before yesterday, when there was no representative of the estate present, or, at least, no one presented himself, so that I was not able to check some assertions at the time which I would gladly have inquired into ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I think I am in a position to answer these.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39274. There was a general allegation made there that whenever it was necessary to provide estate officials with some land, the land was subtracted from the small holdings and not taken from the larger ones?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I can tell you nothing about that, because that must have been a long time ago. It came upon me as a complete surprise, and I was not aware of it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39275. Perhaps Mr Peacock can give 6ome information about that?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: My experience extends over the last twenty-five years, and the only case in which I am aware of any change of that sort was when it was necessary to square up the allotments in the neighbourhood of the ground officer's present croft. They are very irregular, and I believe there may have been some land taken from the immediately adjoining crofts, but not seriously to damage their value so far as I am aware. I would have been prepared with particulars if I had known what was coming.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39276. You might have had an opportunity by attending at the meeting, but, however, I can give you some particulars here. The first assertion was that some parts of the holdings of fifteen crofters were taken off some years ago to form a holding for the local ground officer; can you tell me what that alludes to?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —It alludes, I believe, to the present ground officer's  holding, the boundary of which was, I believe, slightly enlarged at the expense of some of the adjoining crofts.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39277. But to an insignificant degree?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I think to an insignificant degree.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39278. There was another assertion that the holdings of nine other crofters were modified under a statement that the ground taken from them was to be planted, but that the ground taken from them was actually formed into a holding for the harbour master?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —That was before my time, and I cannot speak of it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39279. In connection with the general assertion that ground had been taken from the smaller holdings, it is stated that, after the great changes in the occupancy of the estate from the years 1814 to 1820, a piece of hill pasture was given to the evicted people settled near Helmsdale, called Breacachy, and then that was taken from them, and they received a better place called Griamacharry, but that that, which was extremely useful to them, was withdrawn from them about three years ago ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I believe that Breacachy was a place up in the interior of the country, not a common pasture in the ordinary sense, but a piece of ground that was let to the tenants of the east coast for a grazing, for which they paid so much per head of cattle sent to it; but, at some time subsequent, although before my time, this piece of Breacachy was taken away and added to a sheep farm, and the tenants got Griamacharry in place of it, which they continued to hold until three or four years ago, when a change was made by the Duke. The Duke put a herd there.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: I know all about the Griamacharry case.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39280. They said Griamacharry was withdrawn?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Griamacharry was a pasture which was not common pasture, but on which they were permitted to herd cattle at so much per head. Now, the consequence of that was that the richer few at Helmsdale, adjoining the common pasture, bought a large stock of sheep, and by their means ate up the grazing of the pasture. The consequence was that the poorer people, who had nothing but horses, must either go and pay money to feed their horses, or forego the pasture of their own hill. The complaints were frequent that the sheep were eating them up, and that they had no means of getting pasture at all. Then the Duke decided that this pasture, which is too limited, should be exclusively devoted to the cattle and horses of the tenants who had the right to it, and that if, thereafter, more land was necessary, it should be provided in another form elsewhere. These were the instructions given at the time. I went myself and met the lotters at Helmsdale. Their remark was, ' How are we to get rid of our sheep; we cannot sell them.' I then, of my own authority, undertook to buy their sheep and pay the price for them, and that henceforward that ground should be devoted to the cattle and sheep of the whole of the lotters. Later on, Suisgill farm —Griamacharry being part of Kinbrace farm —was given over to them upon the terms which have already been made known to the Royal Commissioners, and that is how that matter stands.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39281. What was done with Griamacharry when it was taken away?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Griamacharry is still unlet.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39282. The new pasture given to the people is nearer their arable land Kimball and then Griamacharry?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am told that Suisgill is nine miles distant, but there are many here who could tell us.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock. I think Griamacharry and Breacachy are equidistant from Helmsdale, and Suisgill is about half the distance—about nine or ten miles. Griamacharry is about twenty miles from Helmsdale.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball. Well, they have it at nine miles now, and they had it at twenty miles before, and they have got it on very much better terms. Mr Greig told you that £120 had been offered by one person, and £300 by another; and the Duke let it for £100 to them.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39283. Then there was a general statement made with reference to the parish of Loth, that when small holders became extinct, the land vacated by them was not distributed among their own class for the enlargement of other small holdings, but that it was consolidated with the farm of Crakaig; and a particular assertion was made, that, during the last twenty years, thirty small holdings had been absorbed by that farm alone ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I have no knowledge of that. It has come upon me by surprise.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: I know there were some small holdings in connection with the farm of Crakaig. By an arrangement with Mr Dudgeon when he got the lease of the farm, as these holdings became vacant by the death of the tenant, they were to fall into the farm. That was the arrangement under which Mr Dudgeon took the large farm of Crakaig, but I am very much surprised to hear that there were thirty. I almost think there must be some mistake as to the number. If it had been three I could have understood it, but I cannot conceive of anything like the number of thirty.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39284. There is a statement with regard to the crofters in a township called Whitehill, that those crofters had been supplied with an extent of grazing for which they were charged ls. separate rent, and that that grazing had been consolidated with the farm of Crakaig, and that the people had not received any reduction of rent ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —That is part of the same arrangement I referred to just now; it is the same tenant and the same farm.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39285. But the piece of grazing, in this case, seems to have been taken from existing tenants, and not from those who had died out naturally ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I think the only grazing that fell into Dudgeon's hands is the grazing that appertained to the tenants now deceased. Having succeeded to their lots, he succeeded to their right of grazing.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39286. Then, there is a general statement with reference to the prohibition of keeping sheep, and the motive which prompted that prohibition?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball. That is the case of Griamacharry. That was the case in which the sheep were taken away for the reason stated, and now they may keep as many sheep as possible on the ground of Suisgill.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39287. But, if I understood the statement correctly the day before yesterday, it pointed to this, that all the small tenants at Helmsdale, and generally in the vicinity, were prohibited by a general estate regulation from keeping sheep, for some particular reason?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I never heard of that. After those three years, when this was done, all the sheep were taken off that ground in order that room should be given for cattle and horses which were legitimately entitled to the grazing—both to rich and poor alike. Then this place, Suisgill, was given, where they may keep as many sheep as they like. Indeed, Mr Greig informed you that they had not enough sheep to put upon it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock, It is the West Helmsdale grazing, I think, that you refer to, my Lord. As to the piece of grazing there, in 1880, and several years preceding that, there had been frequent complaints from some of the tenants who had no sheep, of the damage done belonging to the other tenants —that sheep came down from the hill and on to their arable lands. They complained very much of this, and said, We have no sheep; we don't want any sheep. Here are our neighbours on this part of the hill ground which was given for a graziug, not for their sheep, but for the benefit of the whole township.' The Duke had it carefully examined, and it was found that that piece of ground was about equal to the accommodation of the horses and cattle in these townships. Marrel had 22 tenants; West Helmsdale, 68 tenants; Gartamore, 59 tenants; and Port Gower, 30 tenants —in all, 179 tenants. Of this number, 111 possessed no sheep at all, and 68 other tenants had on about 356 sheep; and these 68 tenants I classify as follows, with reference to their stock: —46 owned among them 119 sheep, equal to about 2½ each; 14 others owned 108 sheep, equal to 7½ each; and 8 others owned among them 129 sheep, or about 16 each; making in all 68 tenants, with 350 sheep. In November 1881 correspondence and meetings took place with the owners of the sheep, and also with the tenants who had no sheep. Sir Arnold and I went down to Helmsdale on one occasion to urge that the hill was originally intended for the horses and cattle of all the township, not the sheep belonging to a part of the number. Sir Arnold offered to take the sheep at a valuation, for it had been explained that, in justice to their neighbours, they could not be allowed to continue the sheep. They ultimately agreed to put away their sheep, and Sir Arnold agreed to buy them. They agreed also to put them away by Whitsunday 1882, which they did not do —at least they were not appearing to do it. I went round among them with a memorandum of agreement, in order to put the matter into form, and some of them signed the agreement, but a great many of them refused. There were only eighteen that would agree to sign this formal agreement referring the valuation of these sheep to two practical men appointed, one by themselves and one by Sir Arnold. Many having refused to sign, in order to carry out what Sir Arnold had pledged himself to to the tenants who had no sheep, that this change should be made, summonses of removal were issued against nine on the 21st of April 1882, and it was explained to the people that if they did put away their sheep and sign the agreement, these summonses should not take effect There was no desire to put them out of their holdings, but there was a strong desire on the part of the Duke to carry out his promise to the people who had no sheep that they should be protected in that way. Ultimately the people agreed to carry out the agreement. I went down to Helmsdale with the valuators. The sheep were valued on the 20th April 1882, and the whole stock on the ground was handed over at a valuator and paid for, and since then the grazing has been kept for the horses and cattle only belonging to the whole of the tenants of these townships.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39288. Then I am to understand that the prohibition to keep sheep was a prohibition enforced in the interests more of a larger class of the tenants than of a smaller class?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly, and it being a violation of the original compact. When it was given to them it was not intended there should be any sheep at all on the hill. It was by degrees that the sixty-eight tenants got sheep.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39289. But you say a certain class of the tenants were molested by the sheep trespassing upon their ground; was that upon their arable ground?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39290. Then is there no sufficient fence surrounding the arable ground and dividing it from the hill pasture ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —None; no sufficient fence against sheep or cattle.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39291. What is the practice in this part generally; is there no surrounding fence at the back of the arable crofts?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, there is an understanding among the tenants that they should herd their sheep and cattle off the arable when the crops are on the ground, and when the crops are off the ground it seems to be the practice that the sheep and cattle are allowed to go on the arable land. But that has become a great hardship, because many of the improving crofters grow young grass. They crop their lands in a more systematic manner than formerly, and they have their young grass in the spring; and it is a great hardship that the sheep should come down from the hill and eat up everything; and not only have there been instances of their eating the little grass there was, but they have come down to the kailyards and eaten every green thing in the gardens.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39292. No doubt they will do so if there is no fence, but is it not usual to provide a boundary fence ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —The tenants of arable lands —crofters —fence their own lands, and if they chose they might erect among themselves a fence to keep off the sheep; but they don't seem to think that necessary, and practically there is no sufficient fence between the arable and the hill ground.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39293. Is there any regulation on the estate by which, by the co-operation of the landlord and the small tenants, a substantial fence could be erected?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —The Duke would be glad to see something of that kind done, but up to this time he has not felt called upon to promise assistance for the erection of fences.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39291. Are the people at all beginning to separate their holdings from one another by wire fences ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —In one or two cases they have done so, but it is quite the exception, and not the ride.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39295. We have had several statements before us here, and also in other parts of the county, with reference to a system of increase of rental exacted upon the death of occupiers. There seems to be some misapprehension or a want of distinct understanding about that, at least so far as the subject has been brought before us. We would like to understand how the practice of increases upon the death of occupiers is regulated or limited. Some have represented to us that it was an unlimited and progressive increase. Others seem to be under the impression that it is a single increase taken and not to be exacted a second time. Can you state exactly how that is?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: Mr Mackay has stated very accurately the rules of the estate, but he has given a colour to them and made one or two omissions which I am sure are quite unintentional on his part. He stated that a tenant and his widow would remain undisturbed in their lot during the period of their lives, and that the successor —the son—would then have his lot valued finally, and the rent charged accordingly. He seemed to think that, because the son worked with the widow, it was always a ground of claim to succeed; and therefore the son, having worked on that lot, and possibly made improvements, ought not to be charged an additional rent; but he forgot that the widow was probably paying a nominal rent, and that he had the benefit of that nominal rent during her lifetime. Had he been made tenant at once, he would have had to pay the increased valuation from that day. Now, there was an omission made by Mr Mackay in regard to wood and lime. These are given gratis to the tenants for the repair and construction of their houses. I am speak ing in the presence of all who know our rules. The slates are given at prime cost on payment deferred —half down, and the rest by  instalments, or by instalments from the first. The wood and lime are gratis.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39296. I want, first, exactly to understand the extent of the limitations upon the increase of rent, and I will put it in this way. I will suppose for instance a widow, who dies, and she is succeeded by a son, and this son at the expiration of the old tenure at a nominal rent obtains the land 'at increased rent Well, suppose by some unfortunate accident this son dies, and is succeeded by a brother within three years, would there be a second increase of rent ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —-Certaiuly not; and not only so, but the rents and valuations are fixed, and as far as I know, up to any future number of years they will be maintained at that rate. They were fixed in 1866 and 1867.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39297. Then the limit of the increase is defined by the valuation ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —By a valuation actually existing, and said to be a very moderate valuation
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39298. And how long is that valuation prospectively supposed to last?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I cannot tell you. I received it as taken in 1866 or 1867, and so far as I know, there has been no intention to increase it. In the course of time, I suppose, there may be a change.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39299. How was the valuation made?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —By two persons appointed—Mr Macdonald and Mr Mackenzie—experts, who were employed especially for the purpose of examining the holdings locally, and who sent in a regular roll of valuation.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39300. And who heard any representation which the crofter or occupier made?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I must presume that. The fact is that that is what I have received as the valuation roll.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39301. There was one particular case alleged of which, perhaps, Mr Peacock knows. When I asked whether there was any case known of a double increase of rental within a limited number of years, the witness instanced the case of a certain Margaret Macdonald, upon whose croft two increases had been taken within seven years?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: I don't remember that case. Macdonald is a common name, but I shall be glad to look iuto the case and give all the particulars.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: Have you any objection to take the case of a rental that was mentioned here —Alexander Gunn's case—because it is one in point?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39302. He says
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —' When my mother died twenty years ago my eldest brother on getting possession of the lot had to pay death premium, or £1 of a rise of rent. This rise was put on on the recommendation of two of the Duke's ground officers who valued our lot. Three years afterwards my brother died, and I became his successor, and I was to pay a death premium of 4s., that being 4s. more than the Duke's servants or ground officers valued my croft at. Four years ago I received a summons of removal, when, on making inquiry, I found that this was an introduction to another £ 1 , Is. of a rise of rent, which I had to pay and pay still. The actual fact is that I pay £ 1 , 5s. per annum more than what his own servants valued my croft at.' That is an assertion of three rises, but not a rise on a change of occupancy?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: He succeeded his brother in the first place, and then, of course, he was treated as a new tenant, and his rent was increased. It was also increased at a subsequent period. There had been some irregularity in that part of the parish and some inquiries were made, and there was very good reason for believing that this man was implicated in some irregularities that had been going on there, and the Duke really had it in view to put the man out of possession of the place altogether, but his Grace decided to leave him in possession, putting up his rent to the valuation as a sort of mild punishment in his case.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39303. It was a case of a penal increase of rent?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Well, it was rather of that character.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39304. But I wish to get at the general impression. The general rule is that there is no successive or unlimited rise of rental?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Not since this new valuation; but before Sir Arnold's time, and during the late Mr Loch's time, my instructions were that on each change of occupancy a nominal change was to be made on the rent, and these changes were sometimes no more than Is. or 2s.; the change was made just to mark a change of the occupation from one name to another, but they cannot be called increase of rental. They were merely nominal increases.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39305. That is all I have to ask at present about the points stated at Helmsdale. I would now desire, Sir Arnold, to ask you to make a general statement of the expenditure of the Duke of Sutherland for the benefit of crofter's holdings during the last thirty years ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball. This is a point of which no mention was made by Mr Mackay. In the course
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: of the last thirty years the expenditure by the proprietor on crofter holdings has been as under:
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Wood and lime, £15,519; repairs to houses, £5986; meliorations, £835; free, £22,340. Advances at 5 per cent, £6768; total, £29,108; average for year, £970.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39306. This is an expenditure for the specific benefit of the crofters' holdings ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes; but apart from that there has been an expenditure in the way of works—wage-bearing works.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39307. If you allow me, I should like to understand about the expenditure on crofters' holdings specifically. There is an average annual expenditure of £970 upon the crofters' holdings?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39308. Can you tell me what the aggregate rental of these holdings would be on which the £970 was expended ? About what rental, in general terms, would that be on ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —It would be very difficult to find out the particular class of holdings on which it was spent. It would be the poorer class of holdings.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39309. Then this expenditure, for the benefit of small holdings, is an expenditure in buildings?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Lime and wood, and repairs of houses. Wood and lime are given where a man wishes to construct a house. There are repairs to houses separately. With regard to meliorations, where there is an entirely new succession, a man has a claim to meliorations, but these successions are very rare indeed. A man and his wife having a life tenancy, and being succeeded by a son, there arises no question of meliorations for improvement. These are extremely rare, and in this case they amount in the Dunrobin district to £660.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39310. When these advances are made in timber and lime for the improvement of the houses, is any charge made upon them ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —None; they are gratis. On advances for reclamations interest is charged.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39311. One or two witnesses have spoken of the sums advanced for reclamation as Government money ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am surprised to hear it. Government money means the Duke's money, as I understand it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39312. There were Government loans for improving land?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —It has nothing to do with that. It is money given by the proprietor, on which 5 per cent, is charged, for reclamation; I should presume they prefer doing it and retaining the life tenure of all their improvements. On the whole estate, for the last thirty years there was £6768 for improvements, on
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: which interest is charged.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39313. Is that exclusively in the form of trenching and draining?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —The usual way is that the ground officer goes and makes a valuation of what he thinks it has cost for trenching and draining, and the tenant pays the interest upon the sum he receives. If it is supposed to be worth £10, he pays 5 per cent, upon it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39314. Are any fences put up between the common pasture of the crofters and adjacent farms 1 We have had one or two complaints about the aggressions of the sheep of the farmers upon the crofters, and so on?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am afraid there is a good deal the other way. There ought to be wire fences, but it is more probably the sheep farmer who has complained very largely of the encroachment of the tenants.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39315. There are probably mutual complaints ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Well, I think so.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39316. But with reference to the erection of fences, do you consider it would be a valuable improvement that the farms should be divided from each other and from the crofters' lands by fences ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly; but if  such a thing were done, the tenants should have some sort of responsibilty in keeping it up, because it is the interest of the small tenant to see that fence put down. His sheep will find grazing elsewhere, and therefore it is better some sort of responsibility should attach to the maintenance of that fence.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39317. Most undoubtedly, if a fence is put up, it should be maintained; but we have sometimes heard that when the small tenants' sheep encroach upon an adjacent farm they are very liable to be impounded, and the small tenant to be fined?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I should like to know any instances. I am not aware of anything of that kind in my time; on the contrary, on the other side I have heard great complaints —in fact, there is one case pending now that
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: is likely to give us some difficulty with regard to the Suisgill grazings. It appears that horses and sheep graze over into the Culgower farm, and I have heard very serious complaints; and I believe it will have to end in a fence being put up. But in putting up a fence there must be some responsibility attaching to its maintenance, or that fence will not be maintained.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39318. You don't find, in fact, that the small tenants press you for fences between them and the large farms?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, I confess I have not. I have had plenty on the other side; and I daresay there are some farmers
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: here who could tell something about it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39319. So much for the co-operation of the landlord in the improvement of the small tenancies as they exist. I would like now to ask you what has been done, or whether anything is being done for the expansion of the existing small holdings, either with reference to the arable or with reference
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: to the common pasture?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —In my time there have been three or four cases. There were two on the west coast, in the Strathan and Inverkirkaig townships. There have been proposals for some time with regard to expansion on the Armadale side, but as the lease is not out that cannot be effected. That is being submitted to the Duke's consideration. At Doll there has been a place attached to them, and also at one or two points—Breacachy and Golspie Tower —but otherwise none at present.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39320. Am I justified in stating that there is an inclination on the part of the proprietor, if it can be properly done, to afford an expansion of pasture to the crofting communities ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —If you take those five instances as an earnest of the fact, I think I may say it is so.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39321. In the cases you mention, have the small tenants been found capable of supplying the stock?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —There is an expansion of ground for their existing stock. It may lead to further increase of stock, but the expansion of ground is for the existing stock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39322. But if they had more ground, we may presume they would keep more head of stock?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly, I presume they would.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39323. In fact, you have not found they could use the additional ground given to them?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, I know you would not find that, because it would not come before you. This is not adding a piece of ground at a distance under lease, but adding it on no charge at all, because you must bear in
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: mind that no hill pasture is charged for on the Duke's estate. It all goes in the form of charge on arable land; therefore, when you see a man's rent is eight acres at £6 or £5, that is understood to include his share of the common grazing wiehout further charge.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39324. Then, in case of a piece of common grazing being withdrawn, there would be a reduction of rent?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly now that would be the case but I know of no instance. But what I mean is that the rent
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: is per arable acre, and that there is no specific charge for the grazing.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39325. But with the accessory benefit of the grazing?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —With the accessory benefit of the grazing without charge, in this sense that the rent he pays includes both.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39326. Can you give me examples of the creation of new holdings as a whole—not only the expansion of the grazing, but the addition of arable ground, or the concession of new arable ground, to small tenants for the purpose of forming new holdings?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly I can give you many instances of people improving their ground, I can give you one, and I believe the man is in this room—John Murray. I should like you very much to inquire how he has done it. Adjoining him there is a piece of ground which has been laid out for the purpose of being converted into crofts of ten acres, but he is the only one who possessed that portion of ground, and as yet we have had no offers for them. What is preferable, and what has occurred in many instauces, is that they have improved the waste land of their own crofts. One of the persons you examined this morning mentioned that he had only five acres of arable land, for which he was paying, he said, £ 3; but he forgot to mention that he had four acres of waste which was termed waste improvable, not hill, belonging to himself exclusively, and that the extra £1 he paid was on the advance of £25 he received for improving this land.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39327. You mentioned a block of land which was to be divided into crofts or holdings of ten acres each?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I think ten acres each.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39328. I want to know whether you have experienced a difficulty in finding tenants for those proposed new buildings?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: Yes.The Duke has a property called Langwell —East and West Langwell —and between these two townships there is a very considerable extent of ground susceptible of improvement; and the Duke, about fifteen years ago, with the view of encouraging the people of the neighbourhood, who had expressed their anxiety to get more land, employed a surveyor to make a report upon this specific piece of land. It was done, and the lots were all marked out on the ground by pins, and the people were made aware that these lots were to be let if they chose to come forward to apply for them, and I have only had applications at long intervals for crofts in that direction. I have sent the parties there to look at the land, and said I would be very glad to see them back again, when we could discuss the terms of their entry, but the thing has never gone further than their going to look at the land. They have never come back to make proposals for reclamation.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39329. Was it to be let on improving leases?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —It was to be let at a nominal rent.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39330. But with a lease or at will?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —The Duke probably would not have objected to give leases if they had desired them, but the tenants on this estate think it better to be without leases.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: We should be only too glad if they would take it under lease, but of course where they get a life tenure they are generally opposed to taking leases, because a nineteen years' lease would place them on the commercial principle, and they might be liable to an increase of rent at the end of the nineteen years, irrespective of themselves or their widows. It would be a hard case if you imposed a lease. I may tell you that leases were imposed many years ago, but on their expiry none of the tenants would renew them. They prefer the life tenure; but if any of them wish to have leases, I believe the Duke would be perfectly willing to give them on the same conditions under which they could get them in any other county. But suppose the two cases of a man with a life teuure and a man with a nineteen years' lease, both working for the improvement of their land. At the end of the nineteen years the man who has occupied on a lease loses all the benefit of it, but the man who has a life tenure retains it for him and his wife during the natural term of their lives.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39331. Have the people regarded their position as one of actual life tenure?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I have never heard a doubt expressed about it. Perhaps the best way of putting that is to see how many evictions have taken place since the Duke came into the estate. They are absolutely limited to eleven crofters, and many of these cases were on account of family quarrels. I make that statement here, and it is quite open for anybody to refute it. I believe no such thing is known as evictions, and that life tenure is the rule.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39332. We heard to-day—referring to the question of consolidation— of a small farm of eighty acres which had been constituted in the middle of the township, the area of which had been withdrawn from the small holdings in favour of a Mr Crawford, an inn-keeper?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, and the farm is below here. I know the farm, and I know the man, but as to the particulars of how that land was used I must refer to Mr Peacock, for I was not here at the time.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39333. When this farm was constituted we were told that there was no reduction of rent in favour of those whose lands were taken for the purpose?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock. The reclamation of that farm was undertaken immediately after the completion of the railway. The railway passed along the one side of a piece of very wet, boggy, useless ground. Even the small tenants themselves attached very little value to it, and on the completion of the railway it became a very prominent eyesore. Everybody coming from Lairg saw this wretched piece of ground, and the Duke was desirous of improving it, and expended a very considerable sum on the improvement of that land. It extends from the plantation on the west side up to the railway fence on the east side.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39334. But the land on which the farm was formed was withdrawn from the occupancy of the small tenants?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —In so far as they chose to avail themselves of i t; but it was so wet and useless that I am sure I could not have found any tenants in Lairg that would have given any appreciable rent for it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39335. You saw no value put upon it?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I don't think it was susceptible of any value. There were some little bits of arable land that are now
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: absorbed in the farm, and that were cut off in the making of the railway, and there was an allowance made to the tenants for the actual arable land that was taken from them.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39336. What is the area of the whole farm?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Under eighty acres.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39337. What is the rental?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock
General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39338. As you say this land was of a very valueless character, there must surely have been a very large expenditure upon it to make it worth £93 a year?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —There has been enormous expenditure upon it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir Arnold Kemball.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: It is part of our reclamations. The total amount of our reclamations is £254,900.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39339. What do you suppose the expenditure upon the land was to reclaim it?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —About £40 or £50 an acre. At Lairg it was £80 an acre.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39340. And this farm, which has been thus constituted, and rendered worth £93 a year, has been rendered so by an expenditure of what?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —£80 an acre; that is, taking it at the same rate as the Lairg reclamations were taken at, with the additional houses.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39341. It was subjected to the same process, in fact, as the rest?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Steam ploughing and trenching, the same as the rest of the lands.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39342. Then the value of £80 a year, though it may be worth that to the present tenant, does not represent the value withdrawn?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —According to my calculations, it represents 1.6 per cent, of the outlay—the actual return on the three farms of Embo, Ballone, and Dalchork.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39343. Then will you kindly go on to the expenditure of the proprietor in wages for works indirectly profitable to this class?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —In one of the returns asked by the Royal Commission, I was required to state what was the rise of the revenue of the estate in a period of thirty years. This table which I now hand in shows the result:

text: 39344. This is the expenditure on the estate during thirty years, as against the revenue?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes. Tbe deficiency, after devoting the whole of the rental of the estate to works on the estate, was £215,371.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39315. You mean that, during the course of thirty years £215,000 has been expended in excess of the rental of the estate?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39316. Including the outlay upon the railway?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, and this is without making any allowance for the domestic expenses of the ducal establishment in Scotland, which you may take at a considerable sum every year.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39347. And those works, so far as labour is concerned, have given employment to the local population?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, and I think the result is seen in the improved condition and the material comfort of the tenants generally.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39348. Can you say what the returns have been in connection with this great expenditure?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I have calculated that on the reclamations it is nil, and on the railways, taken in conjunction with the whole railway system, it is only 2 per cent., and that on a capital of £350,000, because the other portion was invested in the Highland Railway system, which does yield a return. The Sutherland and Caithness never yielded anything. The Duke of Sutherland's railway has yielded, on the last occasion, 2 ¾ per cent.; the Sutherland railway has yielded 1 ¼ per cent., and that since 1875 only.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39349. Is the result of this great expenditure at all evident in the improvement of the general rental of the estate?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Certainly, the general rental of the estate has increased very much, but totally incommensurate with the vast outlay which has been made to produce that increase.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39350. Has the increase of rental upon the estate been in the direction of shooting and sporting profits?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, I suspect mostly sporting. But that must not be taken entirely as increase without outlay,  because lodges and other expenses connected with it go a long way to reduce any interest on the outlay.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39351. Has there been of recent years any withdrawal of land from profitable occupation—such as sheep farming and otherwise—for the constitution of deer forests ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes, in two instances. One was at Loch Inver, where, on the lease falling out, and being unable to let it again, except at an enormous depreciation, after taking away portions to give to the townships it was made into a deer forest, but unhappily we lost the rent for three years, and it will probably take some time still before we can let it as a forest.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39352. In constituting any ground as a forest, has any ground in the occupation of crofters—either arable or pasture —been taken up?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No,certainly not
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39353. No ground has been withdrawn from small tenants?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, not in any form whatever. I am speaking of my own time, because we had never had any forest here before except the two old forests of Dunrobin and Reay; but, with regard to the forests that have been made in the last thirty years, there have been only the two that I have mentioned.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39354. And what has been done has not been in any sense to the prejudice of the small tenants'?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —In no sense whatever. Will you allow me to refer to the question of population? Mr Mackay talked of the congestion of it, and he seemed to regret that there is a reduction of the population, but I think that must be a sign of prosperity, particularly as represented in his own person. If there are means of occupation and employment, and if the railway furnishes that, it is surely a matter of congratulation rather than that the lots themselves should be divided and subdivided. I don't enter into the question of the clearances, whether they were right or wrong. They took place eighty years ago, and we have to deal with facts as they are. Now, we can imagine what would have been the state of matters if that population had remained to subdivide and subdivide lands declared at present to be too small, though, by the way, in Rogart the average is about seven acres to each person.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39355. Mr Cameron.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Will you just answer one question about the labour that is prevalent here? What labour is there for the crofters? Is there plenty of it, easy of access?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I should say that now they must go some distance to get it, because the reclamation works are stopped. All the railway works have ceased.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39356. Do you find as a rule, that they go distances to get labour to make money to bring home for their families ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes; and I will give an instance of a very recent case of smearers coming from the west coast to the east coast large arable farms. They have no proper arable farms on the west coast, and they come over and get wages. They are paid their expenses to and fro, and get 2s. 6d. a day.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39357. I am afraid that smearing is going out of fashion owing to the low price of wool. Don't farmers take more to dipping than smearing ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I daresay it may be so. I am merely giving that as one instance. There are no public works now except the Brora works, and a wool factory, where there is some small employment of labour, but all this large employment—such as the reclamations and the railways —has for the moment ceased.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39358. Do you anticipate from that cause much distress in the immediate future among the crofters?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, I hope it will give them a sport in improving the waste land attached to their crofts. It is quite in
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: their power to do that, apart from the hill grazings. It is called improvable land, and some have done the work very well indeed. I can instance a case at Helmsdale of a man named Mackintosh, and Murray whom I mentioned before, and others who have done the work very well indeed.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39359. Mr Fraser-Mackintosh.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Can you state what has been the rise of rental in the last thirty years upon the Sutherland estates all over?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am afraid I cannot give that just now.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39360. I observe by the valuation roll of 1882-83 the total of the county, exclusive of railways, is £91,000. Do you think the Duke has £80,000?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I should think so. I would not commit myself to figures, but I think it is more than £80,000.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39361. I want to contrast the expenditure with the increased value of the estate now; has it risen £20,000 in the last thirty years? In 1855 the valuation of the county was £44,789, and at the present time it is £92,564?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock. You may take it that the Duke has 80 per cent, of the whole county.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39362. Then I would like to know what you think it would be twenty years ago; would it be £40,000?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Sir A. Kcmball. Take four-fifths of £44,000, and it will give you the Duke's rental.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39363. That is about £35,000. Then, dealing in the same way with the £92,000, we have £73,000. Taking one from the other, we find that it is practically doubled?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39364. Now when you state that, with all these outlays on the part of the Duke of Sutherland, there is a deficiency of £245,000 in the matter of revenue and expenditure, must you not fairly consider the increased value of the estates ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Most undoubtedly.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39365. Well, what ia the value of the property in Sutherland; is it thirty or thirty-five years' purchase?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I suppose it would be thirty years, under present conditions.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39366. At that rate, don't you see the estate has risen in these thirty years to the extent of one million sterling?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —On an expenditure of more than a million to do it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39367. You say there is only a deficiency of £245,000?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —But a deficiency of all laid out on the estate —not a deficiency of £245,000 with the rental employed to his own purposes, but actually laid out on the estate. I have given you the railways and .the reclamations, and these bring the deficiency above the rental. The rental has gone to pay that.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39368. But in this valuation the railways don't appear on the roll?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —They do appear on the roll.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39369. Yes, to a certain amount, but that is merely the land and not the value of the stock the Duke holds in them?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —But the value of the stock is nil for the Sutherland and Caithness railway at present; and, as to the others it is 2 ¾ per cent., since 1875, on the Duke of Sutherland's railway, which is seventeen miles long; and 1¼  on the Sutherland railway.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39370. You admit that, within the last thirty years, the Sutherland estates are worth one million more than they were then?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —With an outlay of nearly a million to get it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39371. Will you explain what you mean by saying that you regard the decrease of the population here as a sign of the prosperity of the locality ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am speaking of the population of the particular district, because the actual population since 1801 is an increase, not a decrease, over the whole county. But when Mr Mackay suggested that the place was congested, and that they had not room enough, though they had seven acres on the average, I suggested that those who would otherwise have been thrown upon this land, and the lots divided and subdivided, had found a good living by being able to emigrate—as represented in his own person. I don't mean to say it is an advantage that there should be a decrease of population anywhere.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39372. You stated that the rule upon the estate of Sutherland was a life tenure; whose life?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —The tenant and his wife, during their respective lifetimes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39373. Suppose the Duke were to die during the lifetime of the tenant, what then?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Nothing whatever. Their tenure would be as good as ever. I take three generations to prove it.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39374. Are you aware that a lease is not binding upon a successor if it is only from year to year?

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39384. The Chairman.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: have heard of cases on both sides; and, where there is no fence it is practically impossible to keep the sheep from straying from one side to another. witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am not competent to express an opinion upon that. Unfortunately, the milk is spilt, and I have nothing to say about it.

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I am not prepared to deny or admit that fact. I may think fences of importance. I don't deny it, but I am not prepared to discuss the point whether good farming requires fences. I should say it did, as a private opinion.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39389. But surely one in your position—administering a very large estate—is bound to set an example to the small people, and I would have thought, perhaps, that fencing was one of the first things you would have devoted your attention to—the fencing of the people's arable lands?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I don't doubt it, but if you know what that means in money you will perhaps make some allowance in that matter.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39390. Can you tell me how many crofters under £ 30 are upon the estate?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I must refer you to my returns to the Commission for that. I think there are 2232 crofters proper.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock
General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes. 1 am giving these figures to the best of my knowledge; I believe I am right in saying so.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39392. Then I will take 2000 for the question I am going to put to you. You have told us that, for the last thirty years, £970 a year has and been laid out directly upon the crofters. That means 10s. a head upon each crofter?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Not quite so much. witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39394. I want to ask you now about what is commonly called the death premium. I understand that two men—Mr Macdonald and Mr Mackenzie—have made a valuation within the last few years?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock
General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Mr Peacock. The case you refer to was, I believe, the case of Janet and Christine Ross. They were sisters, both infirm, and quite unable to work the land. It was quite apparent that it was impossible for them to work the land, and they were doing nothing to it; in point of fact, they got notice that they must give it up. Summonses of removal were issued against them to compel them to give up the land of which they were making no proper use, and they were put out of legal possession. The two sisters were left in the house till another new house was built for them at the Duke's sole expense, quite close to the previous house. One of the women—Janet—is still living in it, and has been living in it ever since she went in. The other sister is dead. The present sister, and the  other sister as long as she was living, got an allowance from the Duke of £3 to make up for the loss of that land, and that allowance has been continued down to the present time.

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I heard that statement, but I
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: have never been able to reconcile that statement with the facts.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39413. It was based upon a calculation that they pay more per acre than the big farmers do ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I have never been able to reconcile that with the facts. If you assume this, that there is a teeming population in the county, and that the land which is now worth 6d. an acre as pasture is arable land fit for crofters to occupy, and that they are all settled on that land—which is represented by so much on the Ordnance map—I have no doubt you will find the small tenant is a better bargain than the other, but taking the land as it is, you cannot put crofters on land that has no arable on it, and therefore you must take things as they are; and as such, I am unable to reconcile the facts with the statement that the small tenants pay more than the large tenants. witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39411. Do you think it would be possible, when some of these leases expire, to extend the holdings of the crofters from them?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —It is not in my power to say anything on that point. I merely show what we have done during the last three or four years as au earnest of what may be done in the future; but I cannot commit myself to anything. I say everything has been in that direction for the last three years, and I have instanced cases in which this extension of land has been made. The Duke, I know, wishes well to his people, and will do what is good to them, but I cannot pledge myself to anything.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39415. So far as you have observed the style of agriculture practised by the small tenants, do you think it is creditable; do you think they are making the best of the land ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —No, not on the whole. I think there are instances in which they have done it very well in Rogart—down on the low ground—but I should not say they make full use of it, and I am inclined to say also that possibly they may not have the means to do it. They must improve by degrees. If you allow me to draw a comparison between what this country was thirty or fifty years ago and what it is now, I think it will be admitted that there is a vast difference in the housing and comfort, and in the social and economic position of the people; and I hope, thirty years hence, you will see a different state of matters still. Nobody allows it is perfect by any means. Everybody admits very much remains to be done; but what has been done, I believe, is an earnest of what will be done. There is another thing I want to point out in connection with this expenditure, showing the rates and taxes paid by the Duke and in proportion to the rental. witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39425. He being the husband of the niece of George Mackenzie ?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —Yes.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39426. You considered practically speaking, that the arrears were hereditary in the family ?

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: 39433. Was there any other special grievances?
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —There were only two cases that Mr Mackay brought forward. It was said—though my name was not mentioned, I understood myself to be the person referred to —that I did on one occasion so far forget myself as to lift my stick to a minister. I most indignantly deny it, and say there is not a word of truth in it. I am ready to admit that, in a very heated discussion at a School Board meeting, I did emphasise some argument I was using. Happening to have an umbrella in my hand, I did lift it up; but, good gracious ! the idea of my lifting a stick to any minister of any parish in Scotland is ridiculous. There was another case, in which I am surprised that Mr Mackay did not make himself more perfectly acquainted with the facts, and that is the case of an assault committed in my office on a tenant.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: [Mr Mackay.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —I only referred to one case.]
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: I believe you referred to two. You said that a factor was unfit for his position who would do such things, and two cases were referred to. One was a case of irritation in my office. The case is perfectly well known. A man came into my office, and gave me the lie direct as to a matter about the facts of which I was perfectly well informed. He so far forgot himself that he chose to use a very offensive expression to me, and I ordered him out. He refused to go out, and then I did so far forget myself as to take him by the collar and put him out; and when it was represented to me, as it was a day or two afterwards, that it was a mistake on my part, I at once wrote to the man and apologised, and he was perfectly satisfied; and I am very much surprised that a thing of that sort should have been brought up by Mr Mackay.
witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

witness: General Sir Arnold Burrowes Kemball, Joseph Peacock

text: —50 per cent, on one years’ rent, and that has been followed by some reductions of rent in cases where large sheep farms were taken when prices for sheep ruled at the very highest. They have gone down so much that it was thought necessary to reduce the rent.
